The second is the collection of charges from registered vehicles to recover the costs of road damage. The third is the payment of vehicle registration charges into a trust fund. The fourth is the distribution of trust funds to the States and Territories for expenditure on roads used by registered vehicles.

The importance of the road transport industry to Australian transport cannot be over emphasised. About 75 per cent of all freight is moved at some stage by this industry. Whilst I do not have any conflict of interest in relation to the two Bills being debated, I should say that I am a member of the Transport Workers Union, and have been for some time. In that respect, I have a keen interest in the passage of these two Bills. For all that, it is an industry that is not without significant problems. The road transport industry has more than its fair share of instability. For the first time, however, the Federal Government has clearly indicated that it is prepared to act to address long standing problems in the road freight industry. It is doing this in co-operation with the State and Territory governments and in full consultation with industry. The interstate road transport legislation is an integral part of the fast-track package proposed by the Federal Government. It is based on the report of the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry.

A co-operative approach of working in consultation with States and industry is not new. It began with the establishment of the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry in co-operation with States and Territories and in consultation with the industry. The States were consulted on the terms of reference and membership of the inquiry. As well, the industry was fully consulted on the terms of reference. The inquiry itself held 25 public meetings including five truck stop meetings. The Federal Minister for Transport, Mr Peter Morris, sought public comment on the report when it was released. This led to further extensive consultation with the industry. Subsequently, the report and the fast-track reform package were both unanimously endorsed by the Australian Transport Advisory Council. This Council brings together the Federal, State and Territory Ministers responsible for transport.

This expeditious endorsement of the fast-track package is consistent with calls for urgent action from respected industry groups and publications. Just allow me to illustrate. Mrs Kathy Robertson, Executive Director of the Long Distance Road Transport Association, has said:
This report is far too good to sit on the shelf and collect dust.
Mr Tony Hargreaves, Executive Director of the Australian Road Transport Federation, has said:
The Federal Government is to be congratulated in moving quickly to seek implementation of the recommendations of the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry.

Truckin' Life and Australian Trucking Action have both called for quick action. The passage of this legislation by the Federal Government will give the impetus to the States to introduce their parts of the fast-track package. In an industry which is national in scope, it is not unreasonable for States to look to the Federal Government to lead the way.

It should be noted that the Federal interstate vehicle registration scheme will not be implemented until the States and Territories have made substantial progress in areas which fall within their responsibilities. As well, it is also fundamental that the States, Territories and industry are involved in the detailed preparation of necessary administrative arrangements. Therefore, the earliest opportunity at which the Federal registration scheme could commence is July 1986. The States will, by that time, implement a number of measures; namely, graduated truck driving licensing; improvements in inter-system railway cost recovery; improved finance arrangements for truck owners; removal of special fees inposed on out-of-state vehicles; and removal of the speed limit differential between trucks and other vehicles outside built-up areas. Each of these is important, but I would like to make mention of just two.

Firstly, graduated truck driver licensing is long overdue, given the size of trucks that are now on the roads. Such a system will allow drivers to gain experience before moving to the larger and more difficult to operate vehicles. This will add to safety on the road. The removal of the speed limit differential will also add to safety because there will be fewer problems with one of the major causes of injury and fatality associated with trucks. I refer to the overtaking of trucks which keep to a lower speed limit than that set for other vehicles on the road. Studies have shown that when the differential is removed there is a closer adherence by large trucks to the speed limit. It seems that if there is a differential the speed limit is broken, and broken greatly. However, for some reason, when the speed limit is the same for both trucks and other vehicles, the truck drivers adhere more closely to the speed limit.

The fast-track package will be of major benefit to the road transport industry and to the Australian community as a whole. It is vital for the Federal Government to maintain the momentum for change, with the support of the States, industry associations and the relevant unions. It cannot be seriously suggested that the Government is acting with undue haste when it is now over two years since the inquiry was initiated, over one year since the inquiry reported and now over six months since the fast-track package was announced.

I would now like to move to matters relating to the vehicle registration scheme. One of the elements of the fast-track package is the introduction of a registration charge to apply to interstate registered vehicles. The National Road Freight Industry Inquiry recommended that the charge be introduced to eliminate an unfair anomaly which presently exists. Interstate registered vehicles currently escape the payment of reasonable registration charges which recover the costs of road damage. The collection of the proposed charges is designed to close off what we might call a loophole which was created by section 92 of the Constitution. It is also designed to achieve equity in the level of cost recovery between interstate and intrastate vehicles.

All charges from the registration scheme will be paid into a trust fund. All funds raised will be returned in their entirety to the States for expenditure on the maintenance and upkeep of roads used by interstate vehicles. The introduction of such a charge is consistent with national transport policy objectives; namely, that users should pay a reasonable charge for community facilities. Asking users to contribute toward road maintenance is not new. I made some inquiries about this and as far back as the year 1346 the first toll for highway repairs was levied in the British Isles. So it certainly is not new.

The charge proposed by this legislation is a charge for the damage that interstate trucks cause to our roads. It is not a tax. The State that I represent, Queensland, has a number of major highways which are used by interstate carriers. I suppose one of the major ones is the Pacific Highway, which takes vehicles from Brisbane interstate over the Queensland-New South Wales border. However, another major highway is the one which runs up through the Darling Downs and out to Goondiwindi, then down to western New South Wales to markets in New South Wales and sometimes even Victoria. Therefore, some of the charges that will be collected will be returned to the State of Queensland. I am grateful that we will now be able to pay for the repair of some of that road damage with those charges. Of course other interstate road vehicles originate in other States and travel well up the eastern seaboard of Queensland, and some charges will be collected from those carriers and applied to the repair of road damage along that route. A great deal of interstate transport also goes out through the north west, to Mount Isa and to the Northern Territory.

The proposed initial annual charge of $1,400 for a typical 38-tonne unit is based on the recommendations in the report of the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry. The Inter-State Commission has been requested to bring this assessment up to date by reviewing the issue of cost recovery. The Commission is to recommend appropriate interstate charges, having regard to equivalent State registration charges and cost recovery charges achieved by competing rail services. It has been asked to report by 30 April next year. Even though it will not report until then it is not sensible to delay the passage of this legislation while awaiting the Inter-State Commission review. It should be remembered that the charge can be varied only by regula- tion and thus it is subject to parliamentary disallowance.

Forty years of history has shown that the States are unable to tackle effectively cost recovery in relation to interstate transport. Previous attempts to introduce a system of road user charges have failed miserably as the legislation of the various States has proved to be inefficient and inequitable. It is for this reason that I look forward to the Bills being passed through the Senate.

In conclusion I would like to say something about the comments made by Senator Vigor. Senator Vigor indicated that he will be moving an amendment relating to the powers of the courts to disqualify an operator by withdrawing his operator's licence. He suggested that the courts should have the power to admonish the operator as an alternative to immediate disqualification but that there should be a limit to the number of admonitions an operator can receive within a specified period. The proposal advanced by Senator Vigor provides greater flexibility for the courts to deal with an offence without having to move to the ultimate sanction of imposing a disqualification upon an operator. The Government accepts that this would provide some reassurance to the industry that a disqualification will not be unfairly imposed upon an operator.

As the Australian Democrats support the Bills, with this amendment which will be moved in the Committee stage, the Government will be prepared to accept an amendment along the lines outlined by Senator Vigor. The legislation is most welcome and I look forward to it being passed through this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on the Interstate Road Transport Bill 1985 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Bill 1985. As has been said by previous speakers, the Bills concern a major industry in Australia-an industry that plays a vital part in our economic well-being and an industry which I think it is fair to say has been somewhat troubled over the years. I am standing here today principally to express the concerns of part of my constituency in South Australia-a large number of the truck drivers, owners and small businessmen in this field who are genuinely concerned about the legislation going through the chamber today. They are not concerned with the report of the May Road Freight Industry Inquiry, which they have in the past endorsed, and they are not concerned about the package as a whole. When some time ago they learnt of and studied the package-we have heard today that the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) has had various meetings throughout Australia to explain the package to the trucking industry-they saw merit in the package and indicated support.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course that package is not what appears in the Bills today; they are only a very small part of the package. The operators find in the Bills that apart from provisions dealing with safety, which the industry welcomes, the balance of the legislation seems to be largely to their economic detriment. I am speaking particularly about the imposition of an interstate registration fee at a level which people in the industry do not know. All they know is that after the legislation is passed, sometime in the future, if complementary State legislation is passed-I will speak about that later-they will have imposed upon them an interstate registration fee. As we know, intrastate registration fees exist at the moment, and I think they average out at around $1,500. An interstate fee is not imposed.

This Bill proposes such a fee and provides two ways in which it can be determined. It can be either a fixed fee or a fee based on the mileage of the vehicle. The truck drivers do not know, as I said, what the fee will be. They fear that it might be a very large sum of money. The Minister for Transport said in his speech that the matter had been referred to the Inter-State Commission for advice on an appropriate fee for repair of roads, the maintenance of roads, resulting from damage by this industry. That Commission is to report to the Minister. It is not due to report until April of next year. The Minister may or may not adopt the report. He may determine another fee on his own initiative. The industry is being asked to endorse this Bill today and it does not know what fee will be imposed upon it. That causes it major concern.

It is simply not good enough to adopt the Australian Democrats' position that they will allow this Bill to be passed today and then watch with interest to see what fee is imposed through regulation. If they do not like it, presumably, they will issue Press releases saying that they do not like it or take some other ineffective action of that kind. Of course, what the truck drivers are saying-those in my State certainly are-is that there is no need to pass this Bill today. It can be deferred while the Government consults with industry and with the States, while the States' complementary legislation is drawn and while the Inter-State Commission continues with its inquiry and reports back to the Government. Then the Government can introduce into the chamber a comprehensive package which will indicate what the fee is to be. If that were the situation truck drivers would have much more faith and comfort in what is being introduced. But, of course, the Government has determined not to go down that road. It has determined, rather to introduce a half package today; that is, the mechanics for the introduction of a new registration fee, a new tax upon this industry.

The truck drivers in South Australia who have been attending public meetings-I attended one a week or so ago and I understand that further meetings were held in the south-east of South Australia last night and today-are not complaining about a fee which is the equivalent of an intrastate registration fee. They accept that because of section 92 of the Constitution and a whole series of cases, which you know well, Mr Acting Deputy President, such is not the case at the moment, and we do not have an interstate licensing fee. They can understand that there is some merit in lining up the industry on both an instrastate and an interstate basis. If they had some assurance that the fee was going to be only that charged for intrastate registrations they would be much comforted, but they do not get any form of guarantee of that in this Bill.

They are concerned, I suppose, at the alternative method of fee calculation, a calculation on the basis of mileage, because that reminds them of the old road tax which they had to pay some years ago and which, as you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and other senators would know, in effect forced many out of business. They are afraid that once the new electronic black boxes are introduced into their vehicles there will be a perfect mechanism for governments in the future to go down the path that was followed once before on a State basis; that is require payment of a road tax calculated on mileage. They say that that is what this Bill is really all about. They say that in providing an alternative method the Government is reintroducing the concept of a road tax, a tax which they say they simply cannot afford.

The Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, as was mentioned in a speech earlier today, has expressed concern to the Senate about this mechanism for determining fees-a mechanism that requires fees to be implemented by regulation. It has been said, particularly by Senator Archer, that there is no need for haste in this matter. We do not know the attitude of the States. I think it is a matter of regret that in the Minister's speech in the other place and so far today we have not heard the attitude of the States. Where are they with their so-called complementary legislation? Are the States agreeing with the package?

In particular, what are the States saying about that part of the package which will force up the costs of railway transport upon which those in this industry are placing so much reliance? I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the package which the industry was sold and which the industry endorsed encompassed the proposition that rail freight rates would be forced up on a more accurate cost recovery basis. The trucking industry, not surprisingly, looking to its own interests, saw that this would make its cost recovery more economical, and it bought the package on that basis.

But is that going to happen? Senator Archer in his speech earlier today referred to the situation in Tasmania. Will rail freight costs in Tasmania go up, as has been promised to the truckies in this total package, to facilitate their economic well-being? One must wonder. I think the trucking industry is entitled to learn from this debate what is the attitude of Australian National and what is the attitude of the States which still control their own rail systems. What is going to happen, for example, in Queensland? Can the trucking industry be told with certainty that the Queensland Government will put up the costs of rail transport in order to make the trucking industry more viable? It has not been said by this Government, and I suspect that this Government does not know the answer but suspects that, in the world of real politics, that simply will not happen. If that does not happen the whole package will collapse and the support for the total package that this Government was able to win from the trucking industry will not have been well founded. In fact, I do not think it is unreasonable to say that the truck drivers will have been misled.

If it is said that that is not so, that the package should be treated as a total package, why is this Government not prepared to introduce it into the Parliament on that basis? When it has the agreement of the States and Australian National, why is it not prepared to do it that way? Why has it, rather, introduced today simply the mechanism for the imposition of the new registration fees? That is why the truck drivers and members of the trucking industry who have been ringing Senator Vigor and me today are really concerned and worried. All they see coming out of the legislation before this chamber at the moment is the imposition of further fees and taxes upon their industry, upon their livelihood, which is tough enough as it is.

What are they saying? They are saying: `Hold the legislation. Show us that the total package can be implemented'. There is no hurry. The Inter-State Commission, as I said, is not to report until April of next year. I say to the Government: Just hold the package back. Do not push the legislation through the Senate today. One must wonder why it is the wish of the Government to do so. One suspects that it is because the trucking industry is only now becoming aware of the potential cost to it of these Bills. The truck drivers are saying that if the Government were genuine it would be prepared to hold this legislation back until it could present to the industry legislation which implements the total package rather than simply that part which imposes new fees and taxes on the industry.

That is what will be proposed in the amendment to be moved in the Committee stage by Senator Archer-the coalition amendment calling on the Government to delay the progress of this Bill until there is proper consultation with the industry and complete and proper consultation with the States in order that the trucking industry that I and others here represent may see that the package will be implemented as a whole and to the industry's benefit, rather than simply to its detriment. That is the call we make to the Government today and which we intend to make in the Committee stage. We do not believe it is too much to ask. We would have thought that the Democrats would be prepared to support us, because Senator Vigor today listed a series of concerns about the Bills. They should agree that the trucking industry is concerned about the Bills.

We heard Senator Archer begin to list the number of ambiguities in the Bill that could be rectified if there were sufficient time. He mentioned in particular the broad description of general safety standards. What are they? Why cannot the industry be given details of them at this stage? What is the urgency when the Government knows that nothing further can be done until well into next year, in any event? In those circumstances why are the Australian Democrats not prepared to support this delay while a proper consultative process takes place? I do not know whether it is because, as Senator Colston said, the Government has indicated it will support the Democrats' amendment, and on that basis the Democrats can claim that they have had a small victory and are prepared to support this Bill to the detriment of the industry. I can only say that we are particularly disappointed that the Australian Democrats will not support us, after we have heard a speech by Senator Vigor which I would have thought would very much justify a delay in the progress of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like Senator Colston, welcome this legislation because it tackles a problem which has been with us for too long. That is not the only reason, of course, that I welcome it, because it is also of particular relevance to the Northern Territory. As honourable senators will appreciate, there is a good deal of road transport within the Territory and between the Territory and the States. It is unfortunate that we do not have a railway north of Alice Springs, so we are dependent upon road transport a great deal.
—You need a change of government.
—We have been waiting since 1911, Senator. Perhaps we might have to wait a little longer.
—We thought we were making some progress, though, before Labor was elected.

—We thought we had when the previous Government offered us one, but that fell through at the time of the election. Of course, as has been indicated by others, we have some problems with shipping. The Australian National Line has a problem. State ships from Western Australia also have a problem. The problem is, of course, that there is so little back loading from the Northern Territory. This means that there is an increase in costs and makes the running of ANL ships and the constant running of the State ships uneconomical.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems that have been observed over the years in the Northern Territory have been many and they have been brought to my attention by the owner-drivers of the Northern Territory and also by those who are in the business of operating. The first one is the fact that drivers are forced to drive for long hours. There is a number of reasons for this. The owner-drivers, of course, have to meet commitments. They find that they have to drive for long hours to make money so that they can repay the commitments on their gear. The drivers who are driving for operators are being pressured to drive for long hours so that the profits stay up. This has had the unfortunate effect in the Northern Territory that some of the drivers have had recourse to drugs. This in itself poses not only a danger to the health of the driver but also to road safety. I am pleased to see that road safety is one of the main features of the Interstate Road Transport Bill 1985.

I recall visiting a station in the Northern Territory when a large road train arrived with a gate attached to the bull bar. The owner of the station asked: `What happened with the gate?' The truck driver said: `What gate?' It was clear that he had been under the influence of drugs. I am not talking about hard drugs, but those which enable a driver to keep operating. He had not noticed that he had driven through the boundary gate-a fairly substantial piece of fencing-and had carried it into the station on the bull bar. This is very important because a man who will drive through a gate in that way will also perhaps drive into another vehicle on the road or put himself or others in danger. Some drivers have said to me that they rely on the noise of the stones from the verge of the road to wake them up when they are driving. As the vehicle wanders off the road, the stones come up, hit the mudguards and wake the driver. Quite clearly, this sort of situation is not good enough and it is one which is addressed in the Bill.

Another problem that has been raised with me by owner-drivers in that over the years they have been held to ransom by some of the forwarding companies in regard to the buying of fuel, tyres and other equipment and the arranging of insurance. Some of the operators have required the owner-drivers to arrange their purchases through the forwarding companies. If they do not do so, they do not get work. The third problem that has been mentioned to me is road safety. Senator Colston has already referred to road safety and I do not need to dwell on it.
The fourth problem that has been raised with me is the matter of the return to the owner-driver. The Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest, 85/167, in regard to the low returns to owner-drivers, states:

One recent survey estimated their return to be $4.64 per hour in 1982-83. The pressure on operators has increased in recent years as their return remained constant while prices increased. As an example, it has been calculated that of the total charge of $8.00 for contract users (or $41.55 for casual users) for the transport of a 10 kg parcel from Sydney to Melbourne the long distance owner driver will receive 63c. The majority of the return ($5.92 at contract rates or $39.47 at casual rates) goes to the freight forwarders.

So it is not surprising that the owner-drivers have complained about the poor returns to them and the difficulties they have in operating. The next problem that I have seen personally-I did not need to have it reported to me-is the damage caused to roads by heavy vehicles. I am pleased to see that this matter has also been addressed in one of the Bills. Again, this is of particular interest to people in the Northern Territory. I am sorry to see that Senator Hill has left the chamber because I am sure he could have influenced the Government of South Australia to give some attention to the condition of the road to the State border.

I was also pleased to see the level and degree of consultation before the package and the legislation were drawn up. Some criticism was raised initially and Senator Hill raised some further criticism tonight. I am surprised at this. I will draw attention to that a little later, because it seems to me that there has been every endeavour to make contact with all of those involved and there has been every attempt to have consultation. I am pleased to see the level of agreement which has been reached. A great deal of the credit for this should be given to the Minister for Transport, the Hon. Peter Morris, and his Department. The Minister stated:

I cannot recall any other transport initiative which has generated and maintained such a degree of goodwill and co-operation between Federal, State and Territory Governments and all sectors of the industry.

It is also interesting to note that an article in the Australian of 17 October had a headline which read, `Industry welcomes Morris package' and referred to the way in which the industry has welcomed it.

I do not want to cover material which has already been covered by Senator Colston and others, but I would like to look at two aspects briefly, so that we can perhaps secure the passage of the legislation this evening. I refer briefly to the treatment of individuals and road safety implications. The legislation that we are debating is an integral part of the fast-track reform package and is based on the report of the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry. It is interesting to see that the package has been unanimously endorsed by the Australian Transport Advisory Council. I mentioned earlier that I was surprised that Senator Hill said there had not been sufficient consultation. Since the establishment of the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry two years ago, the constant contact between the Department and the industry and the comments which have been made by the Minister and by the newspaper-which obviously would have referred to the industry before it issued a headline such as `Industry welcomes Morris package'-clearly there has been broad support for this package, which is very pleasing to see. It is also interesting, and I think of merit, to note that the legislation will be proclaimed only when the States and Territories have made substantial progress with their parts of the fast-track package. The legislation provides for the registration of interstate vehicles and the licensing of operators but only, of course, to complement the schemes which will be introduced by the States and the Territories.

Let there be no doubt that road safety is the only basis on which operator licences can be lost. It is unfortunate that some people have suggested that licences can be lost for other reasons. Special provision is made for all administrative decisions to be appealable to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Interstate vehicle operators licences can be removed only by a court. At its heart, the introduction of operator licensing is designed to improve the protection available to individual truck drivers, particularly those who are owner-drivers. Owner-drivers under current conditions end up having to carry a full responsibility for road safety violations, even where business pressure is being imposed by others. Operator licencing will ensure that those operators who call the shots will have to accept responsibility for their actions.

The legislation calls for standard monitoring devices to be introduced. This is most essential because quite clearly the information on vehicle speed and the hours of driving can be obtained only from these sorts of devices. The legislation provides that the supplying of this information may be required. That is absolutely essential. Clearly, the Federal Government has paid particular attention to ensure that the rights of the individual are respected by the legislation. The Government would not proceed on any other basis. The legislation ensures a fairer deal for the owner-driver and other grass-roots operators who are trying to do the right thing. Those with the interests of the industry at heart will be better off if the legislation plays its part in weeding out what we might call the shonks.

I have just a few words to say on road safety. I have indicated that in the Northern Territory this is particularly important because of the long distances travelled and the state of some of the roads. Interstate road transport legislation is a concrete expression of the Federal Government's commitment to assist State governments in reforming the road freight industry. For too long these deep-seated problems have been crying out for action but have been left to fester. The fast-track reform package for the road freight industry has a substantial impact on improving road safety. Of course, most of the safety recommendations made by the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry impinge on State and Territory government responsibilities. That is why I indicated earlier that the legislation will not be proclaimed until there has been this sort of discussion.

My colleague Senator Colston spoke about driver licensing-the requirement for truck drivers to gain experience on smaller trucks before driving the big rigs. This will have a great advantage in road safety. People will not be able to pass a simple test, buy a large rig and put themselves on the road where they may be a danger to other people. Senator Colston also spoke of the removal of the speed differential between trucks and other vehicles and the effect that will have.

In conclusion, I welcome the legislation and congratulate the Minister. The legislation will improve road safety. It will improve the lot of the owner-drivers. I believe it will lead to a more efficient industry and I think it has particular advantage for those of us in the Northern Territory because of the remoteness of our area and the long distances which have to be travelled. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to take up a lot of the Senate's time this evening on the Interstate Road Transport Bill 1985 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Bill 1985, however there are a few matters that I would like to raise. I commence by saying that everyone I have spoken to agrees with the intent of this legislation. They agree that the safety problems in long distance heavy road transport have been serious and they agree that these problems need to be addressed. They also agree that some of those problems are adequately addressed in this legislation. As Senator Hill said, the complaints that have come about the rush to put this legislation through are not complaints that contain objections about any of the safety requirements. They are not complaints that contain objections about having to register vehicles. They are not complaints about getting over the situation that has existed for some time whereby interstate road transport people could pay a very nominal fee compared with what people in the trucking industry intrastate pay. They do not have those sorts of objections. However, they do have some concerns. Their concerns are raised in part by the speed with which the Government appears to want this legislation to pass through Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand the argument about the damage caused to roads by heavy vehicles. I support that in some way or another they should, therefore, pay more towards the upkeep of roads throughout Australia. I also comment with respect to the amount of consultation that may or may not have gone on with respect to this legislation. We have been told by a number of speakers that the consultation has been terrific. We have been reminded of the `Industry Welcomes Package' headline in the newspaper. However, there have been other headlines in the newspapers that perhaps have not agreed with that. In the Advertiser today, the South Australia daily newspaper, there is quite a big headline which says `Minister attacks drivers for fear-mongering'. I regard the article as being most discourteous if it adequately reflects the comments of the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris). I draw certain parts of the article to the attention of the Senate. In part, the article says:
A local transport drivers' group has been accused by the Federal Minister for Transport, Mr Morris, of `fear-mongering' over planned new legislation.'

Dealing with that point in particular, I ask: If there has been so much consultation on this legislation, if such a large part of the industry is happy with this legislation and if nearly everybody in the industry is comfortable that this legislation should be passed now, why is the Minister concerned that certain people in South Australia do not want this legislation passed now? Those people want the legislation postponed and they want further consultation. I accept all the arguments that have been raised; that a degree of consultation has gone on. However, I submit that this article is indicative of the fact that the Minister has sensed that in certain pockets of the industry there is dissatisfaction with this legislation. If the Minister did not sense that, why did he respond in such a-`vicious' might be an excessive word to use-way if there is no concern? If these local transport drivers in South Australia do not have any support, why did the Minister bother to respond? The article goes on:
Mr Morris said in Canberra that statements made by the president of the Professional Transport Drivers' Association of SA, Mr Barry Lewis, were at odds with the rest of the trucking industry.
To put honourable senators in the picture, it continues:

Mr Lewis was reported in The Advertiser commercial vehicles pages on October 5 as having serious concerns over the Interstate Road Transport Bill which has passed the House of Representatives and is to be debated in the Senate.

-I ask again: If Mr Lewis does not have a point, if Mr Lewis has no support, why is a Minister bothering to respond in such a childish and vicious way by accusing this man, who is genuinely concerned with the industry in which he is involved, of fearmongering? I hesitate to suggest that part of the Minister's concern might be that Mr Lewis has, on a number of occasions, stood as a Liberal Party candidate for a Federal seat in South Australia. Perhaps being attacked in this way by the Minister is, in part, the price he pays for doing that. But even if that is not the case-I come back to my original point-why would the Minister bother to put out a Press release attacking these drivers for fear-mongering if they do not have any support? What is particularly interesting about this report of these drivers' fear-mongering is the Press release that the Minister put out a few days ago, which states:

Mr Morris said he appreciated the delegation's support for much of the legislation, including the introduction of graduated driver licensing, uniform speed limits, greater consumer protection for owner operators and improved cost recovery for railways.

There are many other paragraphs in this statement and none of them have anything like the tone that the acticle in today's Advertiser has. I can inform the Senate that I had a meeting with these transport drivers in Canberra on Monday of this week. It was a very difficult meeting to organise. We had organised to meet the drivers at 10.30 but, all of a sudden, the Minister showed a particular interest in what these people had to say. Therefore, they rang up and said: `At last we can get an appointment with the Minister, so will you postpone your meeting.' Naturally, being the semi-gracious person that I am, I agreed to postpone the meeting. I postponed the meeting to 11 o'clock. We sat around until 11 or 12 minutes past 11. I then rang the meeting room at which the Minister was meeting with these people and said `Look, I have some senators and members'-admittedly they were senators and members from the coalition side; there were none from the Government side-`and some members from the Liberal and National Party transport, aviation and communication committee here'. I was advised by someone who I understand was the Minister's Senior Private Secretary that these people were meeting with the Minister. I cannot imitate the gentleman's tone, but I gathered that he was not very appreciative of my pointing out that senators and members were waiting. I would identify this man as something other than `this man' if he had had the courtesy at the time to identify himself, which of course, he did not have. He then said: `But, of course these people are much better off with the Minister than with any meeting of old senators'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Old senators?

—That was a mistake. I had identified myself by saying: `This is Amanda Vanstone speaking'. I did not say `Senator Vanstone' because I think that normal courtesies on the telephone should be extended to people whether they are senators or not. However, I did hang up from that phone call in a semi-mild state of rage believing that I should go to the nearest bookshelf and buy a primer on politics for this staff member of the Minister so that he could add up the numbers in the Senate and see whether, at that stage, he could be confident in saying that these people were better off with the Minister than with any meeting of old senators. Naturally, being the youngest member of the Senate I took particular offence. I did not care for this reflection on the Senate either.
—You are doing a very good job, too.

—Thank you very much, Senator. We had to send these people away again. We were told by this gentleman that he had told someone about 10 minutes earlier that he needed half an hour. So senators and members came back from their offices to Senate Committee Room 3 at half past 11. At 11.40 I made yet another call, or tried to, but they had taken the phone off the hook. Perhaps I should withdraw that. I do not suggest that they had taken the phone off the hook; I suggest that the phone was off the hook and, therefore, I could not get through. I wanted to explain that these members and senators were awaiting yet again. Mr Acting Deputy President, you know as well as I do that we all have work to do. We are all happy to make time to meet representatives of various industries who come to see us and generally, on both sides of the House, we are happy to accommodate each other in seeing these representatives because we all have a concern to see that the legislation that is passed through the Parliament is passed with the concurrence and acceptance of as wide a range of industry representatives as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: At 12 o'clock I went back to the House of Representatives Committee Room 4, I think it was, and the drivers were still there. Some people outside were more annoyed than I was. They were members of the Caucus communications committee. I was inclined to think that I should write to the Minister and explain to him that a person I now know to be his Senior Private Secretary should have been invited to stay for the meeting of the Caucus communications committee because he might have learnt something. He would have learnt that it would have been a courtesy not only to senators and members but also to the industry representatives who were there to ring where those representatives were meant to be going-namely, the meeting that I had organised-and indicate that there would be some delay. So on that basis we see a number of things. We see, on Monday of this week, the Minister who had only half an hour-he had another meeting after that and definitely could not stay after 11 o'clock-staying until 12 o'clock to meet with these industry representatives. He gave them an hour and a half. It was bad luck for the people who had the 11 o'clock appointment. They were shunted off somewhere else. Following that, the Minister put out a Press release which was in absolute glowing terms. Another paragraph reads:
The Minister for Transport, Mr Peter Morris, said that he had had an amiable and productive meeting with representatives of the South Australian Professional Road Transport Association.
The discussions, held yesterday, involved various provisions of the interstate road transport legislation currently before the Senate.
In glowing terms he continues:

We clarified several points in the legislation-particularly two misconceptions held by the Association, one regarding the level of the Federal Government registration fee and the other regarding safety provisions.
It went on in the tone:
The Minister is quite happy with the meeting he has had.

Something happened between Monday and today because today the Minister attacked the drivers for fearmongering. This Minister, who had so much consultation with such a wide range of the industry, and was happy to put this Bill forward-he is happy to say that it should be passed now-decided that these people are fearmongering. I put it to the Senate that the reason the Minister issued whatever release he did today that warranted this headline was that he now understands the degree of concern there is in the industry for certain aspects of the Bill.

I come back to my original point: I do not want there to be any misunderstanding in the Senate that the South Australian members of the industry who are concerned about the Bill are trying to get out of paying any registration fee or disapprove of legislation being introduced that increases road safety; it is not that at all. They have a genuine concern that this legislation is being rushed through the Parliament and they do not believe they have been given adequate answers on what the registration fee will be. They do not believe that they have adequate answers in respect of what they regard are draconian provisions which can ultimately remove someone from the industry for life.

I spoke with these representatives when the Minister issued the Press release in glowing terms-not his fear-mongering one. He arranged for me to have a copy of the Press release. I spent some time on the phone with the drivers because they were very agitated. They said that it was absolutely outrageous for the Minister to suggest-as this Press release suggests-that they had had a glowing and friendly meeting. They were not saying that there were any arguments or that there was any unpleasantness. They were saying that they did not believe that the Press release told the full story. To put it in a colloquial term, their noses were somewhat out of joint. Having seen the headline `Minister attacks drivers for fear-mongering' in the Advertiser today I imagine that their noses are even more out of joint. The Government does not pay the air fares for these people to come here and put forward their views. This money comes out of their own pockets.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should maintain your rage.

—That is right; I quite agree. Let me put three points in very clear perspective. I am talking about the Minister who has had loads of consultation, who all of a sudden wanted to snatch the meeting time that I had arranged with these representatives, who said that he could give them only half an hour but who gave them an hour and a half, who put out a Press release indicating the meeting with industry representatives was most amiable and that all of the problems had been solved and who, a few days later, put out another Press release attacking the drivers for fear-mongering. I should not have to say any more. I think that the Minister's behaviour in this regard has been roughly the same as that of the gentleman whom I spoke to on the phone-who was not courteous-and that is disgraceful.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the Australian Democrats will not support the coalition in ensuring that this Bill is not passed and that there is further consultation. I hope that the comments I have made indicate that there should be more consultation. I do not care if someone says: `It is only South Australia'. We are sick of people saying that. If the industry in South Australia is upset about the legislation there should be further consultation. Senator Robertson has just said: `This legislation will be proclaimed only when the States have done their part'. If that is the case, if this legislation will be proclaimed and come into effect only after the States have done their part, why in anyone's name do we have to rush this legislation through the Parliament now? Why can we not wait and have greater consultation with the South Australian people who are concerned?

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the attitude of each of the States?

—The honourable senator may well ask. I am not sure whether the Minister knows the attitude of each of that States. What is particularly interesting is the Democrats' attitude. I ask the honourable senators who are in the chamber and those who will later read Hansard to turn back their minds to the Democrats' jingle-I do not know whether it is still their jingle-of `let's keep them honest'. Even if at the very last minute concern is raised about a Bill-I do not care whether it is two minutes before it is due to be passed-and that Bill does not need to be passed for some very special reason, the honest thing to do is to go back to the people and allow more time for consultation. Why will the Democrats not support that? It seems perfectly reasonable to me. I cannot understand it. I am waiting for the next election in South Australia when, I will peruse the Democrats' advertisements in a closer way than I have perused them in the past. In future my comments on their advertisements will be very well informed and backed up with examples of where their behaviour does not match up to their slogans. The honest thing to do in this matter would be to have further consultation. I cannot express strongly enough why I believe this legislation should be postponed. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, who is sometimes called other things, has often said: `This is a government that wants consensus'.
—Consultation, we hear about.

—As Senator Hill says, we hear about consultation. Yet we have being rushed through the Parliament legislation which the Government Whip says will be proclaimed only when the States have done their part, much much further down the track.
—With the support of the Democrats.

—It will be rushed through the Parliament with the support of the Democrats, as Senator Hill says. I think that is absolutely disgraceful. I would not be doing my duty as a senator representing South Australia if I did not express the concerns of South Australian road transport people and make it very clear to the Senate that their concerns are not that safety requirements will be put on this industry. Their concerns are not that these trucks will have to be registered in a way that they have not been in the past. Their concerns are that something is up. The Minister is not explaining all. He has been inconsistent in his approach. First of all he had consultations. He then made time to have more consultations. He issued a friendly Press release and then issued a very aggressive one. I think road transport people have every right to be concerned.
—Why all of a sudden has the Government joined with the Democrats to push it through today?

—Senator Hill has just asked why all of a sudden the Government is wanting to rush this legislation through the Parliament with the support of the Democrats today? If we had a crystal ball and if we could understand the negotiations that go on between the Government and the Democrats we might understand why it is happening.
—The reason is that the industry is waking up.

—Senator Hill has again interjected. He said that the reason this legislation is being rushed through the Parliament is that the industry has woken up. As I said earlier when Senator Hill was not in the chamber, an article in today's Advertiser headed `Minister attacks drivers for fear-mongering' indicates that the Minister has begun to see that the South Australian road transport people have a point and that they have some concerns. If they do not have the numbers why does the Minister bother putting out a Press release attacking them? I think it is absolutely disgraceful. The Government has not said why this legislation needs to be passed. Honourable senators have spoken about safety, road redevelopment and using registration fees to do this but none of them has said why this should be done. That is a simple question and it is all we want answered. When this legislation will not be needed until next year, when it will not be proclaimed until each State has done its part and when we know from Press releases issued in the Minister's name that there are concerns about it, why does this Bill need to be rushed through the Parliament now? If this Bill is so good as certain parts of it are, it will stand up to a little more scrutiny and a little more consultation. But if it contains something with which the industry would not be happy the Government might have to change things. If the legislation is so good it will stand up to any consultation and a small delay. There is no need to rush this Bill through.
—This Government does not believe in real consultation.
—That is quite right. This Government does not believe in real consultation.
—That is why I asked a question and why I am going to speak on the adjournment. It is a con instead of consultation.

—Now that I hear Senator Peter Rae will speak on the adjournment about the lack of consultation and the fact that this may be a con, I think it is an inducement for me to conclude my remarks. I certainly hope I have made my point. South Australian road transport people are not happy with this Bill. They want further negotiation; they should be given the right to have further negotiation. This Government, which claims to be a consensus Government, should give it to them. The Democrats want to keep them honest. I do not think I can use in Parliament the word that Senator Chipp sometimes uses, but honourable senators know what I mean. They say that they are going to keep those-I delete the word-honest. I do not think that, in planning to assist the Government in rushing this legislation through, they are in any way living up to that slogan.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: South East Queensland Electricity Board Workers-Mr Donald Chisholm-Swan Island Lighthouse

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 6.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I intend to make some remarks about a National Party Minister of the Queensland State Parliament, Mr Lester, often referred to as the Minister for walking backwards and more lately he has been referred to as the Minister for dunny doors. As honourable senators will be aware, earlier this year a dispute involving South East Queensland Electricity Board workers was high on the political agenda in Queensland. Certain SEQEB workers were sacked because they went on strike. The ultra right wing minority National Party Government in Queensland regards many workers as slaves. It does not accept that any workers have the right to strike.

SPEECH.PARA: I interpose just to mention that today members of the National Party in the State Parliament in Queensland apparently went on strike. It seems that it is all right for them to do so. I return to the main point that I wish to raise. The striking SEQEB workers naturally received some help from their union which, in turn, received some financial assistance from community supporters. On 27 June this year Mr Lester was reported as saying that he had the names of 105 sacked SEQEB workers who were collecting the unemployment benefit. An article in the Brisbane Telegraph under the headline `SEQEB ``dole cheats'' 105 sacked men ``living high'' ', stated:
Mr Lester has handed all the details to the Social Security Department to investigate.
Mr Lester today said that the department had assured him that his allegations would be investigated.
The Minister claimed some of the men were earning three incomes and worked as sub-contractors to SEQEB contractors while they collected up to $180 a week in unemployment benefits.
Mr Lester claimed that each time the men signed Social Security forms they broke federal laws because they earned up to $150 a week tax free.
He said they were given a $50 food basket each week and handed up to $100 in cash from the strike fund.
The Brisbane Telegraph, referring to the 105 sacked SEQEB workers who Mr Lester said were allegedly illegally collecting the unemployment benefit, went on:
He said the information had been supplied to him by `impeccable sources' and he had no doubt it was accurate.

Mr Lester accused the former SEQEB employees of `living high on the hog illegally' and claimed they were given the $100 to `heckle'. `It's been revealed to me that as long as these people turn up and sign on two mornings a week before 7 o'clock to heckle, they're assured of $100 tax free,' Mr Lester said. `They're collecting their $180 legitimately. But what they're not telling the Social Security Department is that they're getting a food parcel and $100 cash. `If they were to declare that like they should their dole payouts would be reduced accordingly.
The article continued:
The Minister also alleged that a `great proportion' of the sacked workers were listed as sub-contractors for some SEQEB contractors.

`In other words, they go and do their two days strike duty and get paid $100, they collect the dole and on the other days they're not doing anything they go out and work on a sub-contract basis,' he said.
`They're getting it three ways.'

Mr Lester, of course, had no facts to back up his statements. All of the information had been supplied to him by `impeccable sources'. When one remembers the `impeccable people' who have been lauded by the Queensland Government-Milan Brych, the cancer quack, Stephen Horvath of `hydrogen car' fame and Dr Shrian Oskar, the oil seeds con man-it is easy to understand the stature of Mr Lester's `impeccable source'. Whatever the case, Mr Lester is a dobber. In industrial relations, scabs and dobbers are equally detested and, incredibly, Mr Lester is the Queensland Minister for Employment and Industrial Affairs.

The point I wish to raise tonight is that Mr Lester did not have the courage to leave any trace of evidence that he actually supplied the names. The evidence seems to suggest that he may have supplied the list anonymously-an action of a person who is unwilling to stand by his convictions. The next day, 28 June, the Courier-Mail reported reaction to Mr Lester's admission that he was a dobber. The Trades and Labor Council General Secretary, Mr Ray Dempsey, succinctly put the view of his members. An article in the Courier-Mail stated:

The TLC general secretary, Mr Ray Dempsey, in a telex to Mr Lester yesterday, said: `The TLC calls on you to provide the names of the 105 sacked workers you have defamed in your allegations of social security fraud.
`Thanks to the cowardly and un-Christian attacks by yourself and your lord and master, the Premier, these men have been defamed as thugs, terrorists and now, as dole cheats and criminals.
There seems little doubt that Mr Lester did send or cause to be sent a list to the Department of Social Security. An article in the Sunday Mail of 30 June stated:
The Social Security Department is investigating claims by the Industrial Affairs Minister, Mr Lester, that sacked SEQEB workers are illegally collecting the dole.
Federal Government sources confirmed this yesterday but they said the investigation was `a matter of low priority'.
Of course, the Queensland Premier had to buy in, and he is reported to have said:
If Lester says it, you can bet your life he's got something.
The Premier, as he usually is, was wrong. A report in the Courier-Mail of 17 July under the heading `SEQEB men cleared of dole swindle' stated:
A Social Security Department investigation has cleared 105 sacked SEQEB workers who a State Government Minister allegedly claimed were `dole cheats'.
The Social Security Minister, Mr Howe, said this yesterday when he criticised Queensland's Employment and Industrial Relations Minister, Mr Lester, for making outrageous claims.
The article continued:

`The department found that almost half of those named-48 out of 105-were not receiving any social security payments. And of the remaining 57, there is absolutely no evidence that they are receiving any other income.

The Courier-Mail reported some typical comments which were made when it was revealed that the SEQEB men were cleared of the charge which apparently had been laid against them by the Minister, Mr Lester. The Courier-Mail stated:
The State Opposition Leader, Mr Warburton said Mr Lester deserved the sack for his cowardly attack, a `low' act which cast a slur over the dismissed employees.
`Mr Lester used to be looked upon as a laughable type,' Mr Warburton said, `But I see nothing funny about him any more.
`He is a dangerous person and a serious threat to any chance of restoring industrial relations stability in Queensland.'
The Queensland Trades and Labour Council secretary, Mr Dempsey, accused Mr Lester of being a purveyor of `nasty, malicious, spiteful and vindictive bald-faced slander'.

The SEQEB workers were, of course, outraged. They did not even know whose names were on Mr Lester's hit list. I therefore asked, under the freedom of information legislation, for a copy of the letter and a list of the names sent by Mr Lester to the Department of Social Security. In part, my request stated:

The request is for a copy of a letter forwarded to the Department of Social Security or the Minister for Social Security. The letter was signed by the Queensland Employment and Industrial Relations Minister, Mr Lester, asking whether sacked SEQEB workers were receiving favourable treatment and attaching a list of about 100 names of such workers. Both the letter and the attached list are requested. This matter was mentioned on page 3 of the `Courier-Mail' on 17 July 1985.
I received a reply, which stated in part:

As to the copy of a letter signed by the Queensland Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations I would point out that no such document exists, however, I have enclosed copies of two notes which were attached to the list of names received by this department.

So apparently a list of names was received-there was no letter to indicate that it was from Mr Lester-and the two notes received have been provided to me, but without the names. The letter that I received went on to say that the list would not be released. The reasons for that decision were given and whilst I do not necessarily agree with them I do not quibble with the non-release at this stage. However, the letter does establish that at least two anonymous letters were received by the Department of Social Security. The first of these hand-written notes reads as follows:
Dear Sir,
Enclosed is a list of names re people who may be receiving dole payments and $100 benefits. Some more names may be following.
The other letter said:
Dear Mr Wadeson,
Here is the same list of names of people receiving $100 week from ETU strike fund who are probably on the dole.
Where possible the wife's name has been added as they may be the dole recipient in some cases.

It is interesting that the spouses' names were added as well. Both letters appeared to be in the same handwriting. The Mr Wadeson referred to was at one stage the Acting Director of the Department of Social Security in Brisbane. I think, though I am not absolutely certain, that he now works with the Department in Canberra. It is difficult to record the actual handwriting in Hansard so I seek leave to table photocopies of the two letters so that they may become public documents.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The answer to Senate Question No. 560 reveals that these two notes were written on plain paper without a letterhead. The list of names was typed and it also was on plain paper without a letterhead. There therefore seems to be clear evidence that Mr Lester or someone on his behalf sent a list of names to the Department of Social Security. Of course he has never denied this. What is relevant is that apparently he did not have the courage to sign the letter himself and did not use his letterhead or a typewriter to communicate with the Department. Rather, he hid in the shadow of anonymity when he had to translate his rhetoric into action. Why he chose to do this is unknown but it does seem to show a lack of backbone. Many of us recall the phrase uttered in anger about Kerr's cur. Standing Orders do not permit me to adapt these words to Mr Lester's actions, but such an adaptation would be quite pertinent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening because in recent speeches in the Senate Senator Bolkus has seriously maligned two honest citizens of my State. I informed Senator Bolkus that I would be speaking tonight, in contrast to previous occasions when Senator Bolkus gave me no notice of his intention to speak. He has made a series of malicious unsubstantiated allegations against Donald Chisholm and Wendy McPherson. These allegations are totally and utterly false. This unwarranted attack is a vicious attempt to smear persons of the highest integrity through the privileged confines of this House. I challenge Senator Bolkus to make outside this chamber the allegations that he has made. I am sure that the courts would then be able to deal with these unfounded statements.

SPEECH.PARA: I can only assume that some base political motive is behind Senator Bolkus's activities. The groundless assertion that Donald Chisholm is unsuitable as a candidate for public office points to a possible motive-raw political smearing. It is a straight out political smear quite out of keeping with the traditions and dignity of the Senate. I intend to show conclusively that Donald Chisholm is quite innocent of the improper allegations and charges that Senator Bolkus has made against him. Donald Chisholm is indeed eminently suitable for public office in South Australia and for public service in the State Legislative Council, for which he is a candidate. However that is a decision for the electors of South Australia later this year or next year; it is not a matter to be decided by Senator Bolkus.

I will briefly mention the scurrilous allegations Senator Bolkus has put before the Senate. They are that Donald Chisholm was ineligible to receive a community employment program grant, that he was involved in the decision that gave him a community employment program grant, that he received the unemployment benefit while receiving income from a business he was operating and that somehow-it is quite unspecified-he has misled the Government. I have said in earlier speeches in the Senate that I will produce documents which refute all the matters raised by Senator Bolkus. I now have such documents in my possession and I intend to vindicate both Donald Chisholm and Wendy McPherson.

Firstly, there is the matter of the community employment program grant under which Mr Chisholm was employed as a research and development officer with Adelaide Community and Educational Television, known as ACE TV. Senator Bolkus claimed that this involved the dishonest adoption of a mechanism of trusts to avoid the provisions of the CEP guidelines. According to Senator Bolkus, Mr Chisholm was not a person to whom CEP grant employment should have been offered; somehow he was outside the ambit of the program's guidelines. In 1984, when the application was made, the following guidelines were enforced by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, which has administered the program from its inception. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a description of the eligibility criteria from the guidelines document.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SECTION 4-PARTICIPANTS
4.1 Eligibility Criteria.

4.1.1 Those eligible to be employed under CEP would be unemployed persons who have been continuously registered for full-time work with the CES and away from full-time education for the immediate past 3 months.
4.1.2 Priority will be given to such persons registered with the CES who have been:
unemployed for the immediate past 9 months or
who have never worked or
who for other reasons (as assessed by the CES) are in need of immediate employment or
who are especially disadvantaged in the labour market including
Aboriginals
Migrants with English language difficulties
Disabled

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Let me quote the first of those priority criteria:

SPEECH.PARA: Priority will be given to such persons registered with the CES who have been-unemployed for the immediate past 9 months . . .

The CEP grant provided employment for a 12-month period. Prior to May 1984 Donald Chisholm had been continuously unemployed since October 1982-certainly a period of at least nine months. Donald Chisholm was registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service during the whole of that period. He was actively seeking paid employment. He complied with the CEP guidelines as a person eligible to participate in the program. Donald Chisholm commenced employment with ACE Television at the beginning of May 1984.

I remind the Senate that it was not ACE Television which was responsible for determining who was eligible for inclusion in projects sponsored by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. The only persons who have ever been eligible for employment under a CEP grant are those who have been recommended for interview by the Commonwealth Employment Service. Without a recommendation for interview from the Commonwealth Employment Service no one, but no one, could be eligible for employment under a CEP grant. That situation remains unchanged today. Mr Chisholm was so recommended.

Donald Chisholm is a highly qualified man. He was looking for work; he had fulfilled the criteria by being registered and out of work for over nine months. The Commonwealth Employment Service was happy to recommend him for interview. For Donald Chisholm it was an opportunity to learn new skills and enhance his prospects for future employment. Donald Chisholm certainly was within the ambit of the community employment program criteria. His ability was known to the selection committee acting on behalf of the board of ACE Television. His suitability came out much further during the interview. He had a keen interest in public television, having been involved in trying to get it introduced in Adelaide since early 1980. Indeed, it would have been discrimination against Donald if he had not been considered for the job. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter from Mr Richard Coy, President of ACE Television, which was delivered to my office today, setting out the chronology associated with Donald's appointment as Executive Research Officer for ACE Television.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
ADELAIDE COMMUNITY &EDUCATIONAL TELEVISION INC.
Office: G.P.O. Box 870,
Adelaide, S.A. 5000
Phone: 51 4423
To Whom it May Concern
The circumstances surrounding the appointment of Donald Chisholm as Executive Officer of ACE-TV under a C.E.P. grant are set out below.

The interviewing panel for the appointment of both positions under the C.E.P. grant was composed of Rick Coy President of ACE-TV, Cathy Robinson Executive Secretary ACE-TV and Ray Buttery Chairman of the Legal and Finance Committee. Mr Buttery was to supervise the project.

On receipt of confirmation of the grant we contacted the C.E.S. and requested some suitable people be sent for interview. After the interviews were conducted the panel was agreed that none of the applicants were suitable. We were about to go back to the C.E.S. for some more people when Ms. Robinson pointed out that one of our hard working board members was out of work. Don Chisholm had been manager of the Birdwood Mill Museum but had been out of work for some time.

I contacted the C.E.S. and asked them was Donald Chisholm registered as being unemployed. Their answer was yes. I then asked was he eligible for a C.E.P. grant. Their answer once again was yes. We then approached Mr. Chisholm and asked him if he would be interested in the position of Executive Officer. After due consideration he accepted the position and at the next Board Meeting resigned from the Board. He worked for ACE-TV for the full 12 months of the project finishing in May.

There were no political considerations in the appointment. The panel, which incidentally represented a full scope of political views, was of the opinion that Mr. Chisholm was suitable for the position whereas the people sent from the C.E.S. were not suitable.
I consider there was no impropriety in his appointment and he proved to be a satisfactory employee.
Yours faithfully,
G. RICHARD COY
President ACE-TV

TALK.START.PARA: — I thank the Senate. In the selection committee's opinion, Donald was the best applicant. Donald Chisholm and I took no part in the decision-making process relating to the appointment. The letter states that the appointment committee comprised Rick Coy, President of ACE Television; Cathy Robinson, Executive Secretary of ACE Television; and Mr Ray Buttery, Chairman of the Legal and Finance Committee. Mr Buttery was to supervise the project. Donald Chisholm had properly distanced himself from all these deliberations, and that is shown by the letter. This week I received from the office of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) a copy of the answer to question No. 412 asked by Senator Bolkus on 20 August this year. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Walsh

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

INTERJECT.PARA: (1) Yes. Mr Chisholm was referred to the CEP project, which commenced on 7 May 1984, because he met the participant eligibility requirements of the Program. Subsequent enquiries by officers of my Department did not uncover any evidence that Mr Chisholm was in receipt of any income at the time of referral to the project. I would point out that CEP participants are not eligible to receive unemployment benefit from the time they commence work on a project. Mr Chisholm ceased receiving unemployment benefit on his placement with the project.
(2) Senator Vigor is on the Board of Management of ACE Television and currently holds the position of Vice President.
(3) No. Mr Chisholm resigned his place on the Board of Management of ACE Television following his placement on the CEP project.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Minister states quite plainly that Mr Chisholm met the participant eligibility requirements of the program. Subsequent inquiries by a departmental officer found no trace of any impropriety.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bolkus made certain claims about family trusts. These claims are a red herring. Senator Bolkus appears to have some type of blind spot. If one mentions the words `family trust' he may assume that something is wrong, underhand or even illegal. Maybe that is a reflection of his own thoughts. However, his whole view point is not sustainable. Donald could have been the beneficiary under a discretionary family trust but, clearly, he was not absolutely entitled to any benefits since the trust was discretionary. Donald Chisholm in fact received no payment under the trust mentioned by Senator Bolkus in the financial year 1982-83 and/or the financial year 1983-84. The trust mechanism is a legitimate procedure designed to distribute the income earned by a small business to members of a family. The trust concerned was established by Mr Chisholm's father, not by Donald Chisholm himself. The deed shows that this occurred on 13 October 1978. I have here a copy of the deed. The trustee was Glen Grove Pty Ltd, and the trust was called `D Trust'. Other beneficiaries include Mr Chisholm's former wife, his present spouse and his four children.

I now refer to the tax returns for D Trust lodged in the financial years 1982-83 and 1983-84, sent to me by Mr Chisholm. I inform the Senate that the annual income of this trust was not inordinately large in either of those years. In 1982-83 the total net income was $4,358 and was distributed to the two youngest children of Mr Donald Chisholm. In the second year the net income was $4,875 and this was distributed as follows: Marcus Phillip Chisholm, $416; Roderick Russell Chisholm, $964; Wendy Anne McPherson, $3,495. D Trust is obviously not part of some mythical scheme to defraud the Commonwealth. It is a small scale family trust, similar to many which have been established throughout this country by families which operate small businesses. The trust was established long before Donald Chisholm sought the unemployment benefit. He did not receive income under the trust in 1982-83 or 1983-84. No impropriety was involved, and to suggest that there was is mindless, if not malicious.

Unfortunately for Senator Bolkus, there is no evidence which even hints at any intention to mislead the Commonwealth. On 8 October Senator Bolkus said that Donald Chisholm had supplied misleading information which amounted to nothing less than a fraud on the Commonwealth. There is and there can be no evidence for this false proposition. Both Donald Chisholm and Wendy McPherson have been scrupulously honest and straightforward in their dealings with departments. Senator Bolkus, who parades an interest in civil liberties, has resorted to some very strange techniques.

I would like to place on record a brief chronology of the events which clarify Mr Chisholm's circumstances. Donald Chisholm has not been in receipt of the unemployment benefit since May 1984. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter from the Department of Social Security dated 11 October 1985 which confirms this.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY
116-118 Reservoir Road
Modbury, S.A. 5092
(P.O. Box 619)
Telephone 265 9511
11 October 1985
Mr Donald W. Chisholm
Co P.O. Box 194,
Birdwood 5234
Dear Mr Chisholm
As requested, this is to confirm that Departmental records indicate that you have not claimed Unemployment Benefit since May 1984.
Yours sincerely
R. COOPER
Manager

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In fact, his benefit was terminated on 4 May 1984, prior to his starting work at ACE Television. Secondly, he was employed by ACE Television from 7 May 1984 to 6 May 1985. Prior to this, Mr Chisholm was in receipt of the unemployment benefit. I refer to his taxation return for the year 1983-84. He was unemployed in that year except from May when he was employed by ACE Television. From 1 July 1983 until just before he took up that position he was on the unemployment benefit. Thirdly, since ceasing work with ACE Television, Mr Chisholm has been registered for employment and he personally has not been in receipt of the unemployment benefit. However, his spouse, Wendy McPherson, has been claiming the benefit. He is listed as her dependant. Wendy McPherson first applied for the unemployment benefit at the end of April 1985-not 29 May 1985 as I believed previously. Wendy McPherson has used the freedom of information legislation to obtain her file from the Department of Social Security and has given me full access to it. In the records of the interview which was conducted on 1 May of this year she is shown as having declared Donald Chisholm as her spouse. She explained that as the hours of her part time employment had decreased she was seeking the unemployment benefit. Subsequently, proof of identity was provided to the Department by Donald Chisholm. His employment with ACE Television was declared to the Department, as was her part time work. Subsequent returns to the Department of Social Security accurately reflect the circumstances. The file is here. It shows no evidence of an attempt to perpetrate a fraud on the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: Donald Chisholm is actively involved in many community organisations. He is a hard working, honest citizen who has contributed much of his spare time to the improvement of public life in South Australia. I seek leave to have a list of the organisations to which Mr Chisholm belongs incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The list read as follows-
DONALD M. CHISHOLM
Membership of Organisations
